articles.headline: Seeking Backers for New Fund, Jared Kushner Turns to Middle East
articles.snippet: Former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law is trying to raise capital for his investment firm and is turning to a region that he dealt with extensively while in the White House.
articles.abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law is trying to raise capital for his investment firm and is turning to a region that he dealt with extensively while in the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a White House adviser in the Trump administration, Jared Kushner took a special interest in the petroleum-rich monarchies of the Persian Gulf.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly, David D. Kirkpatrick and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: New ‘Variant of Concern’ Fuels Global Fear of Another Virus Surge
articles.snippet: Scientists do not yet know how dangerous the new Omicron variant is, but its many mutations set off alarms, lowering hopes of putting the pandemic in the past.
articles.abstract: Scientists do not yet know how dangerous the new Omicron variant is, but its many mutations set off alarms, lowering hopes of putting the pandemic in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world reacted with alarm on Friday to the highly mutated new coronavirus variant discovered in southern Africa, as the United States, the European Union and nations across the globe imposed new travel restrictions, financial markets swooned and visions of finally emerging from the pandemic started to dim.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: Israel and Iran Broaden Cyberwar to Attack Civilian Targets
articles.snippet: Iranians couldn’t buy gas. Israelis found their intimate dating details posted online. The Iran-Israel shadow war is now hitting ordinary citizens.
articles.abstract: Iranians couldn’t buy gas. Israelis found their intimate dating details posted online. The Iran-Israel shadow war is now hitting ordinary citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of ordinary people in Iran and Israel recently found themselves caught in the crossfire of a cyberwar between their countries. In Tehran, a dentist drove around for hours in search of gasoline, waiting in long lines at four gas stations only to come away empty.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: In Minneapolis Schools, White Families Are Asked to Help Do the Integrating
articles.snippet: In a citywide overhaul, a beloved Black high school was rezoned to include white students from a richer neighborhood. It has been hard for everyone.
articles.abstract: In a citywide overhaul, a beloved Black high school was rezoned to include white students from a richer neighborhood. It has been hard for everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When Mauri Friestleben learned that Minneapolis was rolling out a new school integration plan — and that the school she led, a predominantly Black, low-income high school, would soon include white students from some of the wealthiest neighborhoods in town — she looked around and proudly considered all that her school had to offer.

articles.headline: What Will the World Be Like in 20 Years?
articles.snippet: Looking at demographic data can help us assess the opportunities and challenges of the coming decades.
articles.abstract: Looking at demographic data can help us assess the opportunities and challenges of the coming decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Demographics are destiny.”

articles.headline: As Omicron Variant Circles the Globe, African Nations Face Blame and Bans
articles.snippet: With countries trying to close their doors to the new coronavirus variant, southern African officials note that the West’s hoarding of vaccines helped create their struggle in the first place.
articles.abstract: With countries trying to close their doors to the new coronavirus variant, southern African officials note that the West’s hoarding of vaccines helped create their struggle in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nations in southern Africa protested bitterly on Saturday as more of the world’s wealthiest countries cut them off from travel, renewing a debate over border closures from the earliest days of the coronavirus pandemic and compounding the problems facing poorly vaccinated countries.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: North Carolina’s Furniture Hub Is Booming. What Comes Next?
articles.snippet: The furniture capital of the state is ground zero for inflation, labor shortages, hot demand and limited supply. It’s debating how to cope.
articles.abstract: The furniture capital of the state is ground zero for inflation, labor shortages, hot demand and limited supply. It’s debating how to cope.
articles.lead_paragraph: HICKORY, N.C. — Six months into the coronavirus pandemic, as millions of workers lost their jobs and companies fretted about their economic future, something unexpected happened at Hancock & Moore, a purveyor of custom-upholstered leather couches and chairs in this small North Carolina town.

articles.headline: What Uber’s Spies Really Did
articles.snippet: A former co-worker accused the men of wiretapping their colleagues, hacking foreign governments and stealing trade secrets. It wasn’t true, but the allegations still follow them.
articles.abstract: A former co-worker accused the men of wiretapping their colleagues, hacking foreign governments and stealing trade secrets. It wasn’t true, but the allegations still follow them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The men who gathered intelligence for Uber were supposed to be ghosts. For years, they were un-Googleable sentries, quietly informing executives about the actions of competitors, opponents and disgruntled employees. But the secrecy of the tightknit team ended abruptly in 2017 when one of its members turned on the others, accusing them of stealing trade secrets, wiretapping and destroying evidence.

articles.headline: As U.K. Beckons Truck Drivers, Many in Poland Say ‘No Thanks’
articles.snippet: A special visa offer, aimed at forestalling a supply chain fiasco during the holidays, goes begging for takers.
articles.abstract: A special visa offer, aimed at forestalling a supply chain fiasco during the holidays, goes begging for takers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks since the British government announced that it would offer 5,000 temporary visas to truck drivers from continental Europe, part of a campaign to reduce supply chain pressure in the run-up to Christmas, Lukasz Skopinski, a Polish trucker now working in the United Kingdom, has offered this advice to friends back home:

articles.headline: Local News Outlets Could Reap $1.7 Billion in Build Back Better Aid
articles.snippet: A small paper like The Storm Lake Times in Iowa would receive a big tax credit. So would Gannett, the nation’s largest news publisher.
articles.abstract: A small paper like The Storm Lake Times in Iowa would receive a big tax credit. So would Gannett, the nation’s largest news publisher.
articles.lead_paragraph: For The Storm Lake Times, a family-run paper in northwestern Iowa, it could mean $200,000 in federal subsidies the first year and nearly $500,000 over the four years after that.

articles.headline: Years of Delays, Billions in Overruns: The Dismal History of Big Infrastructure
articles.snippet: The nation’s most ambitious engineering projects are mired in postponements and skyrocketing costs. Delivering $1.2 trillion in new infrastructure will be tough.
articles.abstract: The nation’s most ambitious engineering projects are mired in postponements and skyrocketing costs. Delivering $1.2 trillion in new infrastructure will be tough.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Honolulu sprawled into new suburbs west of Pearl Harbor over the last two decades, city planners proposed an ambitious rail transit line that would sweep riders 20 miles into downtown. The $4 billion estimate in 2006 was hardly cheap, amounting to $200 million per mile.

articles.headline: The Woman on the Bridge
articles.snippet: Police and prosecutors spent five years chasing a domestic violence case. Would it be enough?
articles.abstract: Police and prosecutors spent five years chasing a domestic violence case. Would it be enough?
articles.lead_paragraph: KITTERY, Maine — At 7:05 on an April evening five years ago, Ryan Sanford, a patrol officer in the port town of Kittery, got a call about a van driving erratically on Route 1.

articles.headline: As China Speeds Up Nuclear Arms Race, the U.S. Wants to Talk
articles.snippet: The Pentagon thinks Beijing may build 1,000 or more weapons by 2030. But it’s the new technologies that worry strategists.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon thinks Beijing may build 1,000 or more weapons by 2030. But it’s the new technologies that worry strategists.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States has no nuclear hotline to Beijing. The two countries have never had an in-depth, serious conversation about American missile defenses in the Pacific, or China’s experiments to blind U.S. satellites in time of conflict.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: As U.S. Hunts for Chinese Spies, University Scientists Warn of Backlash
articles.snippet: A chilling effect has taken hold on American campuses, contributing to an outflow of academic talent that may hurt the United States while benefiting Beijing.
articles.abstract: A chilling effect has taken hold on American campuses, contributing to an outflow of academic talent that may hurt the United States while benefiting Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. agents spent nearly two years tailing the professor, following him to work, to the grocery store, and even keeping his college-age son under surveillance. They told the university where he held a tenured position that he was a Chinese operative, prompting the school to cooperate with their investigation and later fire him.

articles.headline: Inside the ‘Misinformation’ Wars
articles.snippet: Journalists and academics are developing a new language for truth. The results are not always clearer.
articles.abstract: Journalists and academics are developing a new language for truth. The results are not always clearer.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoons this fall, top American news executives have dialed into a series of off-the-record Zoom meetings led by Harvard academics whose goal is to “help newsroom leaders fight misinformation and media manipulation.”

articles.headline: Europe Revisits Nuclear Power as Climate Deadlines Loom
articles.snippet: While wind and solar ramp up, several countries, including France and Britain, are looking to expand their nuclear energy programs. Germany and others aren’t so enthusiastic.
articles.abstract: While wind and solar ramp up, several countries, including France and Britain, are looking to expand their nuclear energy programs. Germany and others aren’t so enthusiastic.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — European countries desperate for a long-term and reliable source of energy to help reach ambitious climate goals are turning to an answer that caused earlier generations to shudder: nuclear power.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Taliban and 9/11 Families Fight for Billions in Frozen Afghan Funds
articles.snippet: The White House must figure out what to do with the Afghan central bank’s account at the Federal Reserve, now blocked under U.S. law.
articles.abstract: The White House must figure out what to do with the Afghan central bank’s account at the Federal Reserve, now blocked under U.S. law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 20 years ago, about 150 family members of Sept. 11 victims sought a measure of justice for their losses by suing a list of targets like Al Qaeda and the Taliban. A decade later, a court found the defendants liable by default and ordered them to pay damages now worth about $7 billion.

articles.headline: Horse Troughs, Hot Tubs and Hashtags: Baptism Is Getting Wild
articles.snippet: In some evangelical churches, a once-staid ritual is returning to its informal roots — and things sometimes get “a little rowdy” along the way.
articles.abstract: In some evangelical churches, a once-staid ritual is returning to its informal roots — and things sometimes get “a little rowdy” along the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russell Moore’s baptism in 1983 was a decorous occasion, or at least as decorous as possible when the main event consists of being plunged underwater in front of one’s entire church. The ceremony took place in a formal baptistery inside his family’s Mississippi church, with a painting of the Jordan River — where Jesus was baptized by John the Baptist — behind the tank. An organ played softly in the background. Mr. Moore wore a long white robe.

articles.headline: Hunt for the ‘Blood Diamond of Batteries’ Impedes Green Energy Push
articles.snippet: Dangerous mining conditions plague Congo, home to the world’s largest supply of cobalt, a key ingredient in electric cars. A leadership battle threatens reforms.
articles.abstract: Dangerous mining conditions plague Congo, home to the world’s largest supply of cobalt, a key ingredient in electric cars. A leadership battle threatens reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: KASULO, Democratic Republic of Congo — A man in a pinstripe suit with a red pocket square walked around the edge of a giant pit one April afternoon where hundreds of workers often toil in flip-flops, burrowing deep into the ground with shovels and pickaxes.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton and Ashley Gilbertson

articles.headline: Made in the U.S.A., but With a Supply-Chain Reboot
articles.snippet: Facing delays, shortages and higher prices for raw materials, small manufacturers are finding new sources. Not all are able to pass along the costs.
articles.abstract: Facing delays, shortages and higher prices for raw materials, small manufacturers are finding new sources. Not all are able to pass along the costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peak season has arrived for DPS Skis, a manufacturer and distributor of mountain sports gear in Salt Lake City. But this year, the winter challenges began far from the slopes.

articles.headline: Twitter’s Jack Dorsey Steps Down From C.E.O. Role
articles.snippet: The social media pioneer, whose name has become synonymous with the company, was replaced by Twitter’s chief technology officer, Parag Agrawal.
articles.abstract: The social media pioneer, whose name has become synonymous with the company, was replaced by Twitter’s chief technology officer, Parag Agrawal.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jack Dorsey stepped down on Monday as chief executive of Twitter, the social media site he co-founded in 2006 and navigated through the tumultuous years of the Trump administration and increasing calls for regulation from lawmakers around the world.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch
